full_text: In this demonstration, I will show you how the product model relates to PolicyCenter at a high level. This is a PolicyCenter screen. I am going to access Ray Newton's account. I am going to do a quick quote for a personal auto policy for Ray Newton's account. Early in the submission process, you are prompted to select a product name. Products are configured using a product model. The product model is at the heart of PolicyCenter's configuration. The product selection looks very simple in PolicyCenter, but the details behind it are all contained in the design of the product model. Before looking more at the product model, let me complete the personal auto submission I began. Ray Newton is the only driver, and he has a Toyota Highlander. Please hold on while I populate all the fields. Here is our quote. Now, let's get back to the product model. Guidewire's product designer tool provides insight into the product model. Let me log in and show you where some aspects of that personal auto product can be managed. Using the product designer, I can locate the specific products that you saw in PolicyCenter. Here is the personal auto product. Take a look at the details that are available for viewing here in the product designer. These are all parts of the product model. Here is the name of the product, as we saw in PolicyCenter. Here is the product description, which also appears in PolicyCenter. You can also have a look at the display key settings for the product. Here is the default for the policy term. Note that you can make some, but not all changes using the product designer. These are the options for the out-of-the-box product. Likewise, the product types for the product are personal and commercial, based on the out-of-the-box configuration. You can also define which type of account the product applies to. Additional changes to the policy lines included in policy terms can be made using these options. This concludes the demonstration.

segments.text: In this demonstration, I will show you how the product model relates to PolicyCenter at a high level. This is a PolicyCenter screen. I am going to access Ray Newton's account.
I am going to do a quick quote for a personal auto policy for Ray Newton's account.

Early in the submission process, you are prompted to select a product name. Products are configured using a product model. The product model is at the heart of PolicyCenter's configuration. The product selection looks very simple in PolicyCenter, but the details behind it are all contained in the design of the product model.
Before looking more at the product model, let me complete the personal auto submission I began.
Ray Newton is the only driver, and he has a Toyota Highlander. Please hold on while I populate all the fields.
Here is our quote. Now, let's get back to the product model.
Guidewire's product designer tool provides insight into the product model. Let me log in and show you where some aspects of that personal auto product can be managed.
Using the product designer, I can locate the specific products that you saw in PolicyCenter.
Here is the personal auto product. Take a look at the details that are available for viewing here in the product designer. These are all parts of the product model.
Here is the name of the product, as we saw in PolicyCenter.
Here is the product description, which also appears in PolicyCenter.
You can also have a look at the display key settings for the product.
Here is the default for the policy term. Note that you can make some, but not all changes using the product designer.
These are the options for the out-of-the-box product.
Likewise, the product types for the product are personal and commercial, based on the out-of-the-box configuration.
You can also define which type of account the product applies to.
Additional changes to the policy lines included in policy terms can be made using these options.
